dialogues.speaker: MAIN TITLES BEGIN
dialogues.text: Writhing pools of light and dark, out of which emerge ima from "The Bride of Frankenstein," directed by James Whale Elsa Lanchester, as the Monster's Bride, looks up, down, left, right, startled to be alive.  The Monster stares at her.  "Friend?" he asks, tenderly, desperately. EXT. COUNTRYSIDE - NIGHT (B & W) Lightning splits the black-and-white sky, revealing a sin shattered oak in a desolate landscape.  Below, a HUMAN SILHOUETTE stumbles through the darkness, the top of his head flat, his arms long and heavy, his boots weighted wi mud. Suddenly the storm fades.  Light creeps into the scene, a color, as we DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE PACIFIC OCEAN
dialogues.text: melting into a hazy morning sky.  In a box canyon off the coast highway, we see row after neat row of trailer homes makeshift village for beach bums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLAYTON BOONE opens his eyes.  He is 26, handsome in a rough-hewn, Chet Baker-like way, with broad shoulders and flattop haircut.  He grabs a crumpled pack of Lucky Strik lights a bent cigarette. Clay stands and walks bare-assed across the single tin ro his head almost touching the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay goes a few rounds with a weatherstained speed bag that's set up behind his trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay towels off, glances at the morning paper.  He moves aside a pile of paperbacks on a card table until he finds calendar.  His finger targets today's first appointment. "10 A.M. - 788 Amalfi Drive."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay steps out of the trailer, clean-shaven and dressed i dungarees, a T-shirt with a fresh pack of cigarettes flip into one sleeve.  He weight-lifts a secondhand mower onto the bed of his rusty pick-up. Clay climbs into the truck, slides the key into the ignition.  It takes a few tries but the engine finally tu over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's truck sails down the road, "Hound Dog" blaring on radio.  MAIN TITLES END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprinklers twirl on a grassy slope outside a rambling clapboard house.  Below, a swimming pool forms a perfect rectangle of still water.  A title reads: SANTA MONICA CANYON.  1957. The pick-up drives past.  Clay parks in the back, hops ou

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: A SHADOWY FIGURE stands at a window, watching Clay unload his red power mower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadow is a man with dove white hair, wearing a dress shirt and seersucker jacket.  This is JAMES WHALE, age 67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have more peace of mind if the live-in nurse were still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was nothing but bother.  I not like her, Mr. Jimmy not like her. We do better if you live-in again, Mr. David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dining room, visible through open double doors, DA LEWIS, 55, speaks softly with the housekeeper, HANNA.  Sh is a squat, muffin-faced Hungarian woman in her late 50s, dressed in black, her hair cinched in a tight bun.  She speaks with a thick accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll contact me if there's an emergency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I call you at this number. (calls out) Mr. Jimmy?  More coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh yes.  Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves into the dining room, sits opposite David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't Hanna a peach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna ignores him, returns to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tells me you haven't been sleeping well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the ridiculous pills they prescribe.  If I take them, I spend the next day stupid as a stone. If I don't, my mind seems to go off in a hundred directions at once --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take the pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to be alert for your visit today.  Especially since I saw so little of you in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remark hits its target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Jimmy.  But with this movie and two difficult stars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The fault, dear David, is not in ourselves but in our stars."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (too anxious to laugh) You remember how a production eats up one's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David.  There's no pleasure in making you feel guilty. (stands) You better go, my boy.  You'll be late for that aeroplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David extends his hand, but Whale draws him into a hug. he starts out, David points to a framed painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I like the Renoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) Goodbye, Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna runs out of the kitchen to escort David to the door Whale drifts back to the window, watches as Clay revs up lawnmower, creating a cloud of white smoke.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bean-pole child with flaming red hair (WHALE at age 12) stares up at the coal smoke pouring from a seemingly endl row of chimneys.  We're in Dudley, a factory town in the English Midlands region known as the Black Country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop lagging behind, Jimmy.  We'll be late for church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale runs to catch up to his six brothers and sisters. father, WILLIAM WHALE, frowns at the boy's prissy trot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straighten up, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Whale's movements thicken into a dim imitation of manly reserve.  The Whale family marches up a steeply mounting street to Dixon's Green Methodist Church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's eyes tighten.  He focuses on Clay Boone as he pee off his T-shirt, revealing a tattoo on his upper right forearm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna?  Who's the new yardman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bone?  Boom?  Something Bee.  I hire him while you were in the hospital.  He came cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale nods, chooses a walking stick.  He emerges into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale moves jauntily onto the front lawn, singing to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bells of hell go ting-a-ling For you but not for me. Oh death where is thy sting-a-ling? Grave where thy victory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale steps up next to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Mornin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Whale.  This is my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your name is --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boone.  Clayton Boone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't help but notice your tattoo.  That phrase?  Death Before Dishonor.  What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that I was in the Marines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Marines.  Good for you.  You must have served in Korea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay shrugs nonchalantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting to be a warm day.  A scorcher, as you Yanks call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I better get on with my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale clears his throat behind the back of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're through, Mr. Boone, feel free to make use of the pool. We're quite informal here.  You don't have to worry about a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glances warily at Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.  I got another job to get to this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale holds Clay's look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some other time, perhaps?  Keep up the fine work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale heads off, smiling to himself.  Pleased to be naugh again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with unframed canvasses, many of them copies of paintings by the Old Masters. Whale rolls out the easel, lifts a half-painted canvas in position.  He stares at the blotches of color, trying to remember what he intended to paint. Whale pulls out a heavy volume on Rembrandt, opens to a black-and-white plate of "The Polish Rider."  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rough pencil outline of the same painting.  Whale, age sits on his bed, ignoring the roughhousing of the three younger BROTHERS who share the room.  The door opens and Whale's mother SARAH enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy.  The privy needs cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my class tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both have Midlands accents, like head colds that flatten their speech.  Whale holds up the sketch to show his moth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get above yarself, Jimmy. Leave the drawring to the artists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale squeezes the pad behind the bed, jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite so, mum.  To the privy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he heads cheerfully out of the room.  His mother shak her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Quite so." (calls out) Jimmy Whale.  Who are ya to put on airs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Whale is already out the door.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale studies his face in the mirror.  He gives his white hair a few final licks with his silver-backed brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale comes in from the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is iced tea, Hanna?  Cucumber sandwiches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Jimmy. (smiles) An interview.  After so many years. Very exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be daft.  It's just a student from the university.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale settles into his club chair and opens a book, pretending to read until Hanna ushers in the visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kay, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning surprise) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale looks up at EDMUND KAY, 22, a slim boy who rests hi weight on one slouched hip, his arms twined behind him. There is a look of mild disappointment on Whale's face as realizes that Kay is a baby poof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Mr. Kay.  I'd almost forgotten. My guest for tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stands and holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale, this is such an honor. You're one of my favorite all-time directors.  I can't believe I'm meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently, teasing) No.  I expect you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is your house.  Wow.  The house of Frankenstein. (looks around) I thought you'd live in a spooky old mansion or villa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One likes to live simply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  People's movies aren't their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly growls out an imitation of Boris Karloff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love dead.  Hate living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay laughs, a high, girlish giggle.  Whale fights a cring with a polite smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my favorite line in my favorite movie of yours.  "Bride of Frankenstein."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it now?  Hanna?  I think we'll take our tea down by the swimming pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clear from Hanna's frown that she doesn't approve of the idea.  Whale ignores her, turns back to Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will that be good for you, Mr. Kay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens the back door) After you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale inspects the boy from behind, noticing his wide hip and plumpish posterior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay's hands flap animatedly as Whale leads him down to th pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the great horror films.  And yours are the best.  "The Old Dark House."  "The Invisible Man."  They look great and have style.  And funny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale points to a small shingled house near the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the studio where I paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice. (refusing to be sidetracked) And your lighting and camera angles.  You're got to go back to German silent movies to find anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay Boone gulps some water from the garden hose.  He glances down at the pool, where Kay and Whale sit in cast-iron chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns to Hanna, who holds a tray loaded with finger sandwiches and a pitcher of iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't move until Clay starts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay flips open his steno pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Kay?  What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything.  Start at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born outside London, the only son of a minister who was a master at Harrow.  Grandfather was a bishop.  Church of...Church of Eng...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's tongue trips on the word, his voice suddenly drow out by the blast of a factory whistle.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fiery melt is poured into molds on the shop floor of a machine parts factory.  WHALE, 16, grips the hot casting with tongs.  His father WILLIAM, his face blackened with grime, hammers away at the flaws.  A heavy blow causes yo Whale to drop the mold, prompting catcalls and sneers on floor.  There is a look of genuine fear in Whale's eyes a he looks up at his singed, beast-like father.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay clears his throat softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale smiles politely to cover his momentary disorientati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father was a schoolmaster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  I attended Eton -- it wouldn't do for a master's son to attend where his father taught.  I was to go up to Oxford but the war broke out and I never made it.  The Great War, you know.  You had a Good War, but we had a great one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances to see if the boy smiles at the quip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't imagine what life was like after the Armistice.  The twenties in London were one long bank holiday, a break from everything dour and respectable.  I had a knack with pencil and paper, so I was hired to design sets for stage productions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna comes down the path with the tray.  She places it o the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Hanna.  Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna remains planted next to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes an audible sigh and starts back up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was one play in particular, a beautiful, grim study of war called "Journey's End".  Every experienced director turned it down, so I offered myself, bullying and begging for the job.  "Journey's End" made the careers of everyone associated with it.  It was only a matter of time until Hollywood beckoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer before we get to "Frankenstein"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I correct in assuming, Mr. Kay, that it's not me you're interested in, only my horror pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, I want to hear everything. You made twenty pictures in all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-one.  The romantic comedies and dramas were much more to my liking.  The horror pictures were trifles.  Grand guignol for the masses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's the horror movies you'll be remembered for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abrupt look of anger flashes across Whale's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not dead yet, Mr. Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I never said you were.  Or will be soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay leans over the steno pad, determined to be more worth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.  "Journey's End" brought you to Hollywood --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale takes in the boy's blank, bored expression.  He sig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a proposal, Mr. Kay.  This mode of questioning is getting old, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make it more interesting.  I will answer any question you ask. But, for each answer, you must remove one article of clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay's mouth pops open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny, Mr. Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, isn't it?  My life as a game of strip poker.  Shall we play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the rumors are true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What rumors might those be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you were forced to retire because, uh -- a sex scandal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homosexual scandal, you mean? For me to answer a question of that magnitude, you'll have to remove both your shoes and your socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay just sits there, squinting and grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dirty old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale tilts his head as if brushing off a compliment.  Ka kicks off his penny loafers, bends over to remove his soc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are kind to indulge your elders in their vices.  As I indulge the young in theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pale feet emerge.  Whale leans forward to examine the He leans back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  There was no scandal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he reaches into his coat for a cigar.  Whale's hand trembles as he slices a hole at the base, then lights the cigar with a wooden match, sucking and rotating until the tip is roundly lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My only other vice.  I suppose you'd like a fuller answer to your question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will cost you your sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay hesitates a moment, then sets his pen aside to pull t sweater over his head, revealing a sleeveless T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too warm for a sweater, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must understand how Hollywood was twenty years ago.  Nobody cared a tinker's cuss who slept with whom, so long as you kept it out of the papers.  Outside of Hollywood, who knows who George Cukor is, much less what he does with those boys from the malt shops along Santa Monica?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay stares at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Cukor?  Who made "A Star Is Born"?  I never guessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take off your vest and I'll tell you a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay plucks at his T-shirt, glancing toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be shy.  There's time to stop before you go too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay peels off the shirt and tosses it on his shoes and sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is famous for his Saturday dinner parties.  Great artists, writers, society folk, all rubbing elbows with Hollywood royalty.  But how many of those oh-so-proper people know about the Sunday brunches that follow?  Gatherings of trade eating leftovers, followed by some strenuous fun and frolic in the pool. (flicks an ash) If a goat like that can continue about his business, my more domestic arrangements could've raised very few eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The revelation seems to have left Kay a little shaken.  h flips to a blank page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk about the horror movies now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Mr. Kay.  Is there anything in particular you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you tell me everything you remember about making "Frankenstein"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances down at his few remaining articles of clothing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can that count as one question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm doing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay stands to unbuckle his belt, glancing around the yard again.  He unzips and steps out of his sharply creased flannel legs.  His thighs are thin and pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like going swimming, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd like a swim when we're through.  I never swim myself, so the pool tends to go to waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  "Frankenstein."  Tell me everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Righto.  Let me see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale swallows a wince, trying to block the pain pushing against his skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Universal wanted me for another story, and wanted me so baldly -- I mean badly, not baldly.  I was given the pick of stories being developed, and I picked that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who came up with the Monster's makeup and look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My idea.  Muchly.  My sketches. Big heavy brow.  Head flat on top so they could take out the old brain and put in the new, like tinned beef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one of the great images of the twentieth century.  As important as the Mona Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?  That's very kind --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale clutches at the air, suddenly notices that his hand empty.  He looks down and sees the cigar on the flagstone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris Karloff.  Where did you find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale bends down to retrieve his cigar -- and the change gravity drives a spike through his skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karloff, Mr. Whale.  How did you cast him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale turns toward the froggy voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  Excuse me.  I must go lie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He forces himself up with one hand.  Kay finally looks up notices Whale's colorless lips and desperate eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?  Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need to -- lie down. Studio.  Daybed in studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale lurches from the table.  Kay jumps forward, catchin him under an arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.  What's wrong, Mr. Whale?  Is it your heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head.  Not heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans against Kay, who leads him toward the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna runs down the path, clutching the front of her apro in two tight fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna swings open the screen door -- and grimaces when sh sees Kay in his BVDs.  He is kneeling next to Whale, who stretched out on the daybed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water.  Glasses at the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to Whale, scooping different bottles from the pocket of her apron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which ones?  I bring them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She empties a pill into her palm.  Whale places it into h mouth and takes the glass of Water Kay passes over Hanna' shoulder.  Whale swallows the pill, then glances up at Ka feigning surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kay.  You're not dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay frantically crosses his arms over his chest and middl turns to Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to take a swim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I spoiled it for you. You should probably go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay hurries outside to retrieve his clothes.  Hanna undoe Whale's bow tie.  She makes no attempt to be gentle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think I'm terrible, Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not think you anything anymore.  Just back from the hospital and already you are chasing after boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shut up.  All we did was talk. My attack had nothing to do with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should get you uphill before the pills knock you cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Let me lie here.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna nods, moves to the door.  Whale closes his eyes, breathes deeply, trying to block the throbbing SOUND in h brain.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise is deafening -- the clank of chains, the screec of wheels and the endless banging of hammers.  William Wh continues to knock away at the hot casting.  The rhythmic sound blends into the insistent knocking of:

dialogues.speaker: A FIST
dialogues.text: which smashes against sheet metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay Boone's eyes dart open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boone!  You awake?  Eight o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me to get you up, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baseball-capped head is visible through the louvered gl in the trailer's door.  DWIGHT JOAD, 30, Clay's neighbor, squints to see inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm up.  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasta la vista, Boone.  And give the jail bait a squeeze for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glances over, seems surprised to see a naked back facing him on the bare mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, um...Rose --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl stirs, turns to face him.  She is 18 at most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to go, Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She presses her naked body against Clay's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know.  I could help you fix up this place real nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay takes a deep breath, trying to clear the gumminess f his brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have to be somewhere? Like high school maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave it up for Lent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy smiles at her own joke.  Clay frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. (jumps up from the bed) Time to hit the road, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale ponders the half-painted canvas, clearly distressed his lack of progress.  The stillness is punctured by the sound of Clay's lawnmower being dragged up the brick step Whale smiles, puts down his brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay stops, turns around, feeling someone's eyes watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) The bells of hell go ting-a-ling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mower slips out of Clay's hands momentarily.  he look around, spots Whale inside the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything alright, Mr. Boone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just got away from me.  Sorry to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen door squeaks open, clatters shut.  A leather slipper and rubber-tipped cane appear.  Whale strolls int view, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just about to ask Hanna to bring down iced tea.  I'd like it very much if you'd join me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stink to high heaven right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The honest sweat of one's brow.  I assure you I won't be offended. Let me tell Hanna to bring tea for two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's cane trembles in his skeletal hand.  His frailty chips away at Clay's resolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or would you prefer a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Iced tea's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay hoses the crumbs of grass off his arms.  He dries hi hands and arms with his hat, then wads it up and stuffs i into his shirt to wipe out his armpits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay stands at the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Mr. Boone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sits on a daybed, next to a pile of newspapers.  He gestures at a wooden armchair across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My workshop, my studio.  Hardly somewhere in which a sweaty workman should feel out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glances at the unframed canvases on the wall and stacked in the corners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are your paintings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but -- are you famous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what they say.  If you have to ask --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a hick who cuts lawns. But some of these look familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were familiar when I painted them.  That one's copied from a Dutch still life done almost three hundred years ago.  And that's a Rembrandt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just copies then.  Gotcha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before I retired, you might say I had a brief time in the sun. Fame, as it were.  Tell me, do you like motion pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, everybody does.  When I was a kid I'd go with my sister twice a week.  Why?  Were you an actor or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my youth, yes, but never in Hollywood.  No, I was merely a director here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  What were some of your movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This and that.  The only ones you maybe have heard of are the "Frankenstein" pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay sits up, surprised, skeptical and impressed all at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Frankenstein" and "Bride of" and "Son of" and all the rest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made only the first two.  The others were done by hacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still.  You must be rich.  Making a couple of famous movies like those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merely comfortable.  Here's Hanna with our refreshments.  Can you get the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay jumps up to open the screen door.  Hanna walks past, refusing to look at him.  She sets the tray on a table ve hard, ringing the glasses and silverware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you feeling, Mr. Jimmy? How is your mind today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mind's lovely.  And yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna flares her nostrils at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember what the doctor tells us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes.  I merely invited Mr. Boone in for a glass of tea. We'll have a brief chat and he'll finish the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not forgetting your last brief chat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go.  We can manage without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna stares up at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks plenty big.  You won't need my help if anything goes flooey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head and marches out the door.  Clay retur to his chair and sits down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they stay in your employ too long, servants begin to think they're married to you. (smiles at Clay) Please, Mr. Boone.  Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she mean by going flooey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I returned recently from a stay in hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing serious.  A touch of stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay nods, chugs his tea.  When he lowers the glass, he finds the old man watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must excuse me for staring, Mr. Boone.  But you have a marvelous head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To an artistic eye, you understand. Have you ever modeled?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, like posed for pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sat for an artist.  Been sketched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) What's to sketch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the most architectural skull.  And your nose.  Very expressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broke is more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But expressively broken.  How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Football in college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went to university?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a year.  I dropped out to join the Marines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  You were a Marine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's gaze deepens.  He laughs lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for going on like this. It's the Sunday painter in me.  Of course I can understand your refusal.  It's a great deal to ask of someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean -- you really want to draw me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed.  I'd pay for the privilege of drawing your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even an amateur artist needs a subject to inspire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's just my head you want? Nothing else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you suggesting?  You'll charge extra if I include a hand or a bit of shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to draw pictures of me in my birthday suit, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no interest in your body, Mr. Boone.  I can assure you of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay takes a moment to size up Whale -- whose innocent, slightly befuddled smile makes him appear about as threatening as a box of cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then.  Sure.  I could use the extra dough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent.  We'll have a most interesting time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale lifts his glass, takes a small sip of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay fetches a pair of hedge clippers from his truck.  He can't help stopping by the side-view mirror to look at hi face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctors and technicians flash lights into Whale's eyes... test his reflexes...inject him with radioactive isotope. Whale sits very still with his head behind a fluoroscope screen while two doctors murmur over the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of X rays are slapped wet on a light board.  Two skulls, one facing forward, the other in profile.  DR. PAYNE, a bland young neurologist, points to a smudge in t side-view X ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the area of infarction.  By which we mean the portion of brain affected by the stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The venetian blinds of the examining room are closed.  Wh sits calmly, flanneled legs crossed at the knees, gazing his own skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lucky man, Mr. Whale. Whatever damage was done by your stroke, it left your motor abilities relatively unimpaired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, Dr. Payne.  But from the neck up?  What's my story there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Payne turns off the light board and goes to the venetian blinds.  The room is instantly full of sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The central nervous system selects items from a constant storm of sensations.  Whatever was killed in your stroke appears to have short-circuited this mechanism. Parts of your brain now seem to be firing at random.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying there's an electrical storm in my head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's as good a way as any to describe it.  I've seen far worse cases.  You might even learn to enjoy these walks down memory lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the rest of it?  The killing headaches.  The phantom smells.  My inability to close my eyes without thinking a hundred things at once. It's all nothing more than bad electricity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a manner of speaking.  I've never encountered the olfactory hallucinations, but I'm sure they're related.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the Luminal to sleep, or whenever you feel an attack coming on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to be saying that this isn't just a case of resting until I'm better.  That my condition will continue to deteriorate until the end of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor responds with a sympathetic gaze.  Whale nods solemnly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale makes his way toward the stairs.  He passes a stoop-shouldered ELDERLY WOMAN who leans on the arm of he middle-aged DAUGHTER.  Then an OLD MAN in a wheelchair, h eyes brimming with bewilderment and despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna opens the door.  Clay wears dungarees and a white dress shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, you already paid me. I'm here because --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Master is waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures him in, shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay follows Hanna into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's down in his studio.  Here. Take this with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thrusts a TV tray toward him.  Two glasses, two bottl of beer, a bottle of Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your job, lady, not mine. (hands back the tray) I'm here so he can draw my picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm keeping away.  What you are doing is no business of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of man are you?  Are you a good man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm a good man.  Something make you think I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not hurt him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a break.  I'm going to sit on my ass while he draws pictures.  Is that going to hurt him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No. (closes her eyes) I am sorry.  Forget everything I say.  Here.  I will take the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay opens the squeaking door and enters behind Hanna. Whale stands at a drafting table, sharpening a pencil. Hanna sets the tray down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Hanna.  Now goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes toward the door, wrinkling her forehead at Clay. The screen door bangs shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'd like something to wet your whistle while I work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale opens a bottle of beer, pours it into a glass, hand it to Clay.  He gestures to a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go slowly today.  Since this is your first time as a model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay sits.  He pulls a "TV Guide" out of his back pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see this?  They're showing one of your movies tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say?  Which picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bride of Frankenstein."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm.  I much prefer "Show Boat" or "The Invisible Man."  Shall we begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay takes a swig of beer and sets the glass on the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready when you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stares at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That shirt, Mr. Boone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  It's too white, too distracting.  Would it be asking too much for you to take it off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not wearing an undershirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pish posh, Mr. Boone.  I'm not your Aunt Tilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's just my face you want to draw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh if it's going to make you uncomfortable... (sighs) Perhaps we can find something else for you to wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts a drop cloth off a footlocker, revealing a stack of "Physique" magazines.  Whale casually covers them with newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could wrap this like a toga around your shoulders.  Would that help you overcome your schoolgirl shyness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right already.  I'll take it off.  Kind of warm in here anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unbuttons the shirt and pulls it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Much better. (steps forward) Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay adjusts his belt buckle as Whale hangs the shirt on wall peg.  He moves back to the easel again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'll have you sit slightly sideways, so you can rest one arm on the back of the chair.  Yes. Just so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arm with the tattoo faces the easel.  Clay smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a picture, it lasts longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what I intend to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clatter of pencils in the easel's tray, followed by a moment of silence.  Finally, a low, whistly scratch.  Cla concentrates on keeping still, focusing on an open window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to have no idea how handsome you are, Mr. Boone.  It has to do with how snugly your face fits your skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay wipes a thin line of sweat from his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be more comfortable barefoot?  Feel free to remove your boots and socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bit like being at the doctor, isn't it?  You have to remain perfectly still while I examine and scrutinize you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale suddenly sniffs, as if smelling something.  He snif several times more but continues to draw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Dripping? (to Clay) Do you ever eat dripping in this country?  The fat from roasts and such, congealed in jars.  Used like butter on bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like something you feed the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.  Only the poorest families ever ate it.  We kept ours in a crockery jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family ate dripping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching himself) Of course not.  As I said, only poor people --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stops.  He lets out a bitter laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I've just realized how terribly ironic it all is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've spent most of my life outrunning my past.  Now it's flooding all over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay stares out blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something about the openness of your face that makes me want to speak the truth.  Yes, my family ate dripping.  Beef dripping and four to a bed, and a privy out back in the alley.  Are you also from the slums, Mr. Boone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We weren't rich.  But we weren't poor either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you were middle class, like all Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you'd say we lived on the wrong side of the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Dudley there were more sides of the tracks than any American can imagine.  Every Englishman knows his place.  And if you forget, there's always someone to remind you.  My family had no doubts about who they were.  But I was an aberration in that household a freak of nature.  I had imagination, cleverness, joy.  Where did I get that?  Certainly not from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's voice has changed, becoming more pinched and nasa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took me out of school when I was fourteen and put me in a factory.  They meant no harm.  They were like a family of farmers who've been given a giraffe, and don't know what to do with the creature except harness him to the plow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale seems completely lost in the past by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatred was the only thing that kept my soul alive in that soul-killing place.  And among those men I hated was my own poor, dumb father.  Who put me in that hell to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale peers out from behind the square of paper.  He pale when he sees his father William, his face covered with grime, glaring at him from across the room.  Whale retrea behind the pad, takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relief floods Whale's face.  He looks out, smiles at Clay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to excuse me, Mr. Boone. Since my stroke, I am often overcome with nostalgia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind.  I'm not crazy about my old man either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale rubs a hand across his eyes and steps into the open

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we break for five minutes?  You probably want to stretch your legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale pulls the cover sheet over the pad to hide what he' drawn so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you just sat there while this old limey banged his gums?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is dead.  There's only Clay and Dwight sitting the bar with the owner, HARRY, a balding hep cat with a scraggly tuft of beard.  And, in a booth, KID SAYLOR, a cocky 20-year-old, necking with a pony-tailed TEENAGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked it.  You learn stuff listening to old-timers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry) You ever hear of this Whale fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't say that I have.  Can't say I've heard of a lot of people though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't believe me, let's watch this movie.  See if his name's on it.  How about it, Harry? Can I watch my damn movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.  I don't turn on the TV except for the fights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETTY CARTWRIGHT appears behind the bar, lugging a bucket ice from the storeroom.  She's an attractive woman in her early 30s, big-boned and almost as tall as Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spooky movie.  Just what this place needs tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't make it any deader, doll. Set me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Your friend want one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay reacts to the silent treatment with a tight smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, one for what's-his-name here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets down two bottles of Pabst without looking at Cla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harry) I say let loverboy watch his movie.  And be grateful Boone's not cutting Shirley Temple's lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is everybody giving me crap tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Boone.  You come in here proud as a peacock because some old coot wants to paint your picture. We're just bringing you back to earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds screwy to me.  I can't imagine a real artist wanting to spend time looking at that kisser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kisser wasn't so bad you couldn't lay under it a few times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooooh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty glares at Clay, who realizes he's gone too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet this is just some fruit pretending to be famous.  So he can get in the big guy's pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooooh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just thinking out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well keep your filthy thoughts to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then.  He's interested in you for your conversation.  We know what a great talker you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore you don't.  Doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explodes) We're watching the movie, Harry. You got that!  We are watching my fucking movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, Clay.  Just calm down. We'll watch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry reaches up, turns on a battered Motorola.  On the t a voice announces: "Tonight, Boris Karloff in 'The Bride Frankenstein.'"  The titles come on.  Ending with the phr "Directed by", which floats over a white blob.  The blob jumps forward to form letters: "James Whale."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there.  What did I tell you? James Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie starts.  The Monster being roasted alive in the flaming wreckage of a mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This looks corny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go wash glasses if you don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a flooded crater under the mill, the Monster kills an man.  He climbs up, flips the man's wife into the pit bel An owl blinks impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad.  Two down and it's just started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie, a hatchet-faced woman with fluttering ribbons, is now alone with the Monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale and Hanna are in bathrobes and slippers, and there a glass of milk and a plate of cookies on Whale's TV tray On the tv, Minnie (played by UNA O'CONNOR) squeaks and whimpers and screams.  Whale laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful old Una.  Gobbling like an old turkey hen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hanna isn't amused.  She unclenches her arms to close the bathrobe over her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that monster.  How could you be working with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, Hanna.  He's a very proper actor.  And the dullest fellow imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie flees in a bowlegged jig up the hill.  Whale smile again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the tv, Dr. Pretorius (played by Ernest Thesiger) delivers a toast with inimitably ripe enunciation: "To a new world of gods and monsters!"  Dwight and Harry and Betty all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These old movies are such a hoot. They thought they were being scary, but they're just funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) Maybe it's supposed to be funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny is funny and scary is scary. You don't mix them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the tinny tv soundtrack is drowned out by the vo of Elvis Presley.  Kid Saylor bends over the jukebox, wagging his denim butt and tapping a high-top sneaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Some of us are watching a movie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.  Free country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay jumps from his stool.  Saylor sees him coming, steps aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to turn it down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay slams the heel of his hand against Saylor's chest. boy staggers backward.  Clay grabs the corner of the juke and jerks it from the wall; the needle scratches across t song.  Saylor holds up both hands in a nervous surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I didn't know.  It's your favorite movie.  Sorry, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay returns to the bar and uprights the stool.  Saylor escorts his girl to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're like a dog with a bone over this movie, Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to watch it, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the tv, the blind man thanks God for sending him a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna's frown pops open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not going to kill the old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Hanna.  My heart isn't that black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a crypt, the Monster meets Dr. Pretorius, who is havin midnight snack on top of a closed coffin.  "Friend?" the monster asks.  "Yes, I hope so," answers Pretorius, witho batting an eyelash.  He offers the Monster a drink, then adds: "Have a cigar.  They're my only weakness."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cigars were my own brand.  So that I could have the leftovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the tv, the Monster groans:  "Love dead.  Hate living. Whale's focus sharpens, prompted by the unexpected discussion of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monster holds a skull in both hands and happily growls, "Wiiife."  Betty, shudders, for real this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick stuff.  Necrophilia.  I wonder if they knew how sick they were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monster's lonely and he wants a friend, a girlfriend, somebody. What sick about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Frankenstein and Pretorius make their final preparations.  Frankenstein inquires where the fresh hear came from.  "There are always accidental deaths occurring Pretorius replies.  "Always."  Once again, Whale responds the talk of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the Bride comes to life.  She looks up, down, le right, uncertain who she is.  The Monster stares tenderly.  "Friend?"  He timidly touches her arm and she screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right!  You don't want him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monster is heartbroken.  Nobody loves him, not even h Bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bride shrieks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monster's pain turns to anger.  He tears through the lab, orders Frankenstein to escape with his wife.  But he wants Pretorius and the Bride to stay.  "We belong dead." Whale reacts sharply to the line. The Monster blows up the laboratory and the movie ends. Hanna shivers as she stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh.  I am sorry, Mr. Jimmy, but your movie is not my teacup. Still, I am glad there is a happy ending.  The bad people are dead and the good people live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hits the button on the Magnavox with the flat of her palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty turns off the Motorola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird movie.  Weird, weird, weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry stands up and stretches.  Clay remains seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loved it.  I want a switch like that in my trailer, so I can blow us to kingdom come when things don't go my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wobbles when he climbs off his stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn but it's getting drunk in here.  Late too.  The bride of Dwight is going to bite my head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tilts toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coming, Boone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll hang around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, Clay.  We're closing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd give you a hand since I kept you open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits to see how Betty reacts.  She shrugs.  Harry tak his book and cash drawer to the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm next door if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Clay one last look and goes out to the breezeway and his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what?  I think you guys are all jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) What's to be jealous of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotten to know someone who's famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so famous any of us have ever heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he were that famous, he probably wouldn't give me the time of day. This way, he's like my famous person. (laughs at himself) Yeah, my own personal famous person.  Who treats me like I'm somebody worth talking to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay leans down to plug in the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go for a swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snaps her mouth open and imitates the Bride's furious cat hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means it's too cold to go swimming.  And I don't mean the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to try anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I'm never going to smoke another cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He patiently waits by the door while Betty turns out the lights.  She walks briskly through the glow of the jukebo waving Clay outside with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty pulls the door shut and bends over to lock it.  Cla catches a glimpse of skin in the side slit of her shirtta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go for a walk at least.  Walk and talk.  I really feel like talking tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's eyes blink in mock surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This old guy -- he's the kind of person I expected to meet when I moved out here.  Someone who's done things with his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize you're more interested in this old goober than you ever were in me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's different.  He's a man.  And by the way you have no business calling him a homo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never crossed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an artist.  Anyway, he's too old to think about sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the old men I know think about nothing but sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door of her Chevy.  Clay grabs it with both hands to keep her from getting in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.  What's eating you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty hesitates, then looks him sharply in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You picked up that girl right in front of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, no strings, right?  That's what you always said.  Just good pals who have the hots for each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It still hurt.  A lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm actually kind of glad it happened.  It made me wonder what the hell I was doing with my life. Letting you pull me into bed whenever the spirit moved you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You liked it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  I loved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you enjoy it, you should do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I just can't do that anymore.  I still have time to get things right.  Get married again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look on your face!  You're not marriage material.  You're not even boyfriend material.  You're a kid. A big, fun, slightly irresponsible kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you then?  What will you be ten years from now?  Still cutting lawns?  Still banging horny divorcees in your trailer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glares at her, his jaw working forward in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like my life.  I'm a free man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you're free, for now at least. But how long before you're just alone?  Pathetic and alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's anger jumps from his jaw into his shoulders and ar He grabs the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't want to fuck.  That's what you're telling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all this conversation means to you?  Am I going to put out or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn straight.  I'm sick of playing games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty quickly gets into the car.  before she can pull the door shut, Clay slams it on her, hard.  Her hands leap in front of her face, as if he'd hit her.  The look of fear her eyes startles Clay out of his rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, look.  This is coming out all wrong --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She frantically turns the key in the ignition and the Che pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From here on out, Boone, you're just another tired old face on the other side of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car screeches away.  Clay stumbles across the highway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay comes to the dump at the end of the canyon.  He clim into it, kicking at loose cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all shit!  Shit on by women! Shit on by the Marines.  Shit on by the world!  Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shouts the word at the cliff, for the raw, sudden violence of shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuuuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog in the carport starts to bark.  The sound of Clay's pain echoes off the canyon as we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale is sitting up n bed when Hanna knocks.  She enters with a tray loaded with bottles and vials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will take them all, Mr. Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be fine, Hanna.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale takes the pills, one by one, until he comes to the bottle of Luminal.  He opens the pheno bottle to shake ou capsule and a dozen spill into his palm.  He stares at th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna opens the door, gasps when she sees Whale lying motionless on the bed.  She spots the empty bottle of Luminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, Mr. Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna kneels next to the body.  She makes a Sign on the Cross, launches into a frantic "Hail Mary."  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale snorts at the imagined scene.  One by one, he retur the capsules to their bottle, until a single pill remains He places it on the table, then turns out the lamp and li on his back in the dark, waiting for sleep. The distant sound of laughter invades the darkness.  Whal sits up, straining to identify the voices.  The bedroom w opposite him melts away, revealing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELSA LANCHESTER and BORIS KARLOFF sit side by side in dentist chairs, cloths around their necks, heads tilted back.  JACK PIERCE, the makeup artist, is patting the hai drawn over a cage on Elsa's head.  He looks up, sees Whal and breaks into a conspiratorial grin.  Elsa's eyes are closed; she hasn't heard whale enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You done yet, love?  I am absolutely dying for a fag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale tiptoes in for a better look.  Karloff has a mouthpiece to help him breathe while the assistant adds another coat of green sizing to the still incomplete makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gurgles) Goo' 'orning, 'ames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.  And a very good morning to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsa's eyes snap open.  There are no mirrors on the walls

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.  The way you look at me, James.  What have you done this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring a mirror.  Let the Bride feast upon her visage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris?  Do I look a fright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karloff shrugs, irked that she's getting all the attentio Jack Pierce lifts a large mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nasal New Yorkese) Behold, the Bride of Frankenstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsa stares at the beautiful corpse in the mirror.  She snaps her head left, right, up, down, startled by the sig of herself, electrocuted into frightened, spastic jerks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Whale observes his star we see her spasms through his eyes -- as a series of dissonant, line-jumping close-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you said there'd be some of me left.  Nobody's going to know me in this getup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense, my dear.  You look extraordinary. (to an assistant) Today's script.  Quick.  And a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale scans the page of shooting script, the margin marke in pencil: CU, MS, MLS.  Whale pencils in a bracket and scribbles: CU a,b,c,d---MOS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I want to get on this right away.  Sorry, Boris, we won't get to you until this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I 'ish you 'old 'e 'ooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assistant removes his mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have spent the morning tending to my roses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of Stage C is completely filled by the laboratory set.  Electricians adjust the lights on the wooden tower beside the Bride's table.  COLIN CLIVE (Dr. Frankenstein) and ERNEST THESIGER (Dr. Pretorius) sit off the side, in full makeup and costume.  Clive mumbles earnestly over his script.  Thesiger pinches his face ove the needle he dips in and out of an embroidery ring. Whale comes on the set with Elsa on his arm.  She walks regally beside him, the train of her long white robe thro over one arm.  There's a wolf whistle from overhead, and applause, causing Elsa to curtsy to her admirers.  Thesig takes her hand, leans back to study her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God.  Is the audience to presume that Colin and I have done her hair?  I thought we were mad scientists, not hairdressers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a mad scientist could do this to a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, my dear.  You look absolutely amazing.  There's no way I can compete with you.  The scene is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the sequel, James, two lady scientists should make a monster. And our monster would be Gary Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would've thought Mr. Leslie Howard would be more your line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More your line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My line nowadays runs to Rin Tin Tin.  Dogs are so much more dependable than men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin?  Please.  It's time. (softly, to Thesiger) How is he today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stiff as a board. (calls out) Yes, Colin.  Come see what they've done to our Elsa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive walks over, glumly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not at my best today, Jimmy. A touch of flu, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sees through the excuse, rests an arm on Clive's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, my boy.  You could do this scene in your sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive grits his teeth and nods.  Whale positions them in front of the upended table, Clive and Thesiger holding Elsa's robe out by the hems.  The shadow of the sound boo passes back and forth while they rehearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gather we not only did her hair but dressed her.  What a couple of queens we are, Colin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsa giggles.  Clive looks distraught -- which brings som life to his stiffness.  Whale sees this, decides to tune higher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, a couple of flaming queens. And Pretorius is a little in love with Dr. Frankenstein, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clive's distress reads clearly now.  He is twitchy and alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I think it's coming together. Shall we have a go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in the canvas director's chair, nods to the assistant director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet on the set!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warning bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights sizzle and blaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay for sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man with a clapboard steps in front of the camera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scene two-fifteen.  Take one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bride snaps her head in various directions.  Thesiger slopes back, fingers splayed, intoxicated by his creation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bride of Frankenstein!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sits with his legs crossed, jogging his raised foot if conducting the scene with his show.  Fully engaged, intensely alive.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale glances at the clock, sees that it is 3:15.  He is wide awake.  He reaches over, picks up the Luminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luminal.  Illumine all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale reluctantly places the pill on his tongue and swallows.  He rests his head on the pillow and stares at ceiling, where the reflection of the window sheers casts ever-shifting pattern of light and dark.  We move down to reveal: INT. PRISON CELL - NIGHT (BLACK & WHITE) It's a cobblestone cell, a plaster set from "Bride of Frankenstein."  Whale sits in a massive chair, straining against thick iron chains, as a lightning storm rages outside.  In the distance, heavy footsteps, coming closer until the cell door is filled with the silhouette of the Monster.  Whale hardly dares to breathe as the Monster ri off the door and enters the cell. The Monster steps into the light, allowing us to see his face for the first time.  It is Clay Boone, dressed in a Marine parade uniform.  He uses his hedge clippers to cut the chains from around Whale's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay leans down and takes Whale in his arms, cradling him like a child.  They move across the sound stage -- Clay carefully sidestepping the lights and cables on the floor until they reach the next set:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay carries Whale past a painted backdrop of a stormy English countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale lies on the Bride's table.  Clay pulls on a doctor' smock, picks up a scalpel from a table covered with vario medical instruments.  he carves a thin circle around the of Whale's forehead.  Then, with one deft movement, he po off Whale's scalp and pulls out the brain.  It is soot-covered, charred, used up. Whale watches with detached fascination as Clay tosses it the floor, then takes a throbbing, luminous mass from a tray.
