Clay inserts the new brain into Whale's skull, sutures th scalp back into place.  he fastens the conducting clamps around Whale's temples, then throws the heavy circuit breaker.  Lights throb with bursts of energy...loose spar crackle...rotary sparks create snapping circles of fire.. the energy of the raging storm is harnessed into the machinery. Clay steps back to take in his handiwork.  A sudden look panic fills Whale's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't working.  The experiment is a failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glances down at Whale, whose breathing is slowing. Realizing that the new brain hasn't taken:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A serenity suffuses Whale's features as he stares up at t pale flicker of lightning.  His breathing finally stops, face a tranquil mask of death.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale wakes with a start.  He checks the clock, sees that it's past nine.  He presses an intercom button on the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm up, Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sits up, drinks in the sunlight.  He notices some grass clippings and leaves scattered on the bedspread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in God's name --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale turns and sees Clay lying next to him.  He gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) I told you to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's hands close around Whale's neck.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale opens his eyes groggily.  He scans the room in pani clearly unable to get his bearings. Whale tries to stand but his legs give way beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale and Hanna stare straight out as she reaches down an unbuttons the tiny buttons on his pajama fly.  Whale supports himself with one hand on Hanna's shoulder as he relieves himself with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sits up in bed, staring dumbly at the morning paper Hanna reaches in to take away the breakfast tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the yardman come today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  This afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thin smile forms on Whale's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay prunes the roses on the front lawn.  Hanna appears, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Master wants to know if you are free for lunch.  I tell him you will be having other plans, but he insists I ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a lawn this afternoon, but I'm free until then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expect nothing fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna goes inside.  Clay rolls the mower down the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay knocks on the bottom of the Dutch door as he lifts t latch and walks in.  He is wearing a fresh madras shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Master is dressing.  I am to offer you a drink.  There is whiskey and there is iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You are a guest now.  You go in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, Hanna.  I'm more comfortable in here.  It is Hanna, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She eyes him suspiciously, shrugs, pours a glass of tea. Clay notices a Bible on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you worked for Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long enough.  Fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you've seen a lot of famous people come and go?  Movie stars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  We live simply, Mr. Jimmy and I.  People come to play bridge. And now and then, young men to swim.  You have people, Boone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean family?  All in Joplin, Missouri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.  Because no girl in her right mind will have me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who is not married has nothing.  He is a man of trouble. You need a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You proposing what I think you're proposing?  Don't you think I'm a little young for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna twists her head around with such an indignant look that Clay bursts out laughing.  She realizes that she is being teased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men.  Always pulling legs. Everything is comedy. (mimics an English accent) "How very amusing.  How marvelously droll."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna stares at Clay until his smile fades.  She resumes chopping in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever been married, Hanna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  I am married still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  What's your husband do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is dead now, twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're as single as I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I have children, grandchildren too.  I visit when I can.  But now that Mr. Jimmy cannot be left very long, I do not get away much. (sighs) Poor Mr. Jimmy.  There is much good in him, but he will suffer the fires of hell.  Very sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what the priests tell me. His sins of the flesh will keep him from heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sins of the flesh?  Everybody has those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  His is the worse. (worse) The unspeakable.  The deed no man can name without shame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She loses patience with Clay's blank look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the good English?  All I know is bugger.  He is a bugger. Men who bugger each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay slowly sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is why he must go to hell.  I do not think it fair.  But God's law is not for us to judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me Mr. Whale is a homo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did not know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...no, not really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and he are not doing things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  That is what I hope.  I did not think you a bugger too.  I fear only that you might hurt him if he tries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to hurt anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I trust you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off in the distance, a throat loudly trumpets itself clea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must go in.  Quickly.  He will not like to think I have had you in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay gets up slowly, reluctant to leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale comes forward as Clay enters, offering a hand at th end of a spindly wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Mr. Boone?  So glad you are free for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume you worked up an appetite with your labor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hesitant smile from Clay.  Whale picks a stack of mail the table, rifles through envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive my rudeness.  At my age, the post is the cream of the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns the stack to the table but holds on to a squar envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks off while Whale opens the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?  Princess Margaret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is examining a folded card.  He rubs a thumb over the printed lettering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Majesty's Loyal Subjects in the Motion Picture Industry... Cordially invited...Reception at the home of...Mr. George Cukor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His lips smack open in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That pushy little -- horning in on the Queen's sister, then offering to share her with the whole damn raj?  I live in this country to get away from this rubbish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the invitation on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this David's doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This David's a friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  An old, useless friend.  You must excuse me, Mr. Boone.  This is a world I finished with long ago. I pay them no mind and expect them to return the compliment. (a deep breath) Lunch should be ready.  Shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out an open hand so that Clay can precede him in the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna sets down two steaming plates of omelettes.  Whale hands a glass of red wine to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both take a sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells lovely, Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna nods, steals a glance at Clay as she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw your movie the other night. Watched it with some friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked it.  We all did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did anyone laugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity.  People are so earnest nowadays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Was it supposed to be funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  I had to make it interesting for myself, you see.  A comedy about death.  The trick is not to ruin it for anyone who isn't in on the joke. (a sip of wine) But the Monster never receives any of my gibes.  He is noble.  Noble and misunderstood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale gazes pointedly at Clay, who eats with his elbows o the table, quickly bolting the hot omelette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Korea, Mr. Boone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you kill anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing to be ashamed of, in the service of one's country. That's something to be proud of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proud?  Any jerk with a gun can kill someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite true.  Hand-to-hand combat is the true test.  Did you ever slay anyone hand-to-hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) No.  I could have, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I believe you could. (a sip of wine) How free is your schedule this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full up.  I got the hedges to do here, then another lawn out by La Cienega.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is we say phooey to the hedges?  Could you spare an hour after lunch?  To sit for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay our going rate.  Plus what you'd get if you did the hedges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  I don't feel like sitting still today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All righty.  I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale tilts a scrutinizing eye at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna carries the dirty dishes back to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay starts to bite the tip off a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale passes him a gold penknife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a trim.  And mine while you're at it.  Fingers are a bit stiff today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever been married, Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  At least not in the legal sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay hands a clipped cigar back to Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you had a wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a husband.  Depending on which of us you asked.  My friend David. He lived here for many years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other cigar crunches faintly between Clay's fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that surprise you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I -- you're a homosexual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.  If one must have a clinical name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think of me that way, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What way might that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know.  Look at me like -- like I look at women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be ridiculous.  I know a real man like you would break my neck if I so much as laid a hand on him. Besides, you're not my type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay suddenly laughs.  Whale's smile deepens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we understand each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you do is no business of mine. Live and let live, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope this has nothing to do with your refusing to sit for me today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale continues to smile, slyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of, Mr. Boone? Certainly not a frail old man like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay has no answer.  He gives in with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay sits sideways on the chair again.  Whale stands at t easel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see what you did so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will only make you self-conscious.  You'll have to remove your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  Not today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we have to match the other sketch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel more comfortable keeping it on.  You just said you didn't want me self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if we open the shirt and pull --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's hands to in.  Clay's flesh tightens; he shrinks back.  The hands stop, palms raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.  I have made you nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.  I'd just rather keep it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose we unbutton the top and pull it down around your shoulders? Two buttons.  Is that so much to ask?  Just two little buttons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's thumb and fingers unpluck buttons in midair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Look.  What you told me at lunch is still very weird for me. So either you sketch me like I am or I'll say forget it and go do your hedges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale takes a step back.  His eyes are locked on Clay, fascinated by his temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be a prick, but that's how I feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  I don't want to scare you off.  Not before I'm finished with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale glides behind the easel.  The pencils rattle in the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me more about yourself, Mr. Boone.  You have a steady companion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how it is.  You have to kiss ass just to get a piece of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is just one kiss-ass game after another.  A man has to make up his own life, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.  A philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoreau with a lawnmower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I like that.  But take care, Mr. Boone.  Freedom is a drug, much like any other.  Too much can be a very bad thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glances out the window.  Feigning a merely casual interest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you and your friend split up?  Because you wanted to be free?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way, yes.  I suppose so.  I know it's why I stopped making pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale backs away from the easel and stares at the paper w a sour frown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might not think it to look at me now, but there was a time when I was at the very pinnacle of my profession.  The horror movies were behind me.  I'd done "Show Boat." Major success.  Great box office. Now I was to do something important.  "The Road Back."  An indictment of the Great War and what it did to Germany.  It was to be my masterpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fucking studio butchered it. It was 1937, Hitler's armies were already massing -- and still the New York bankers stood in line to curry his favor.  Anything to avoid losing the German market.  They cut away the guts and brought in another director to add slapstick. The picture laid an egg, a great expensive bomb.  For which I was blamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow passes over Whale's eyes.  He presses two finger against his temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that, I went out of fashion. I was no longer able to command the best projects, so I walked away.  Why should I spend my time working in such a dreadful business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you miss it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) It's so far in the past now.  Over fifteen years --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stops himself.  He smiles gently at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making movies was the most wonderful thing in the world. Working with friends. Entertaining people.  Yes, I suppose I miss it.  More so now that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale reaches into his pocket, takes out the bottle of Luminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we all want to feel we've left our mark on the world.  Yes. I wish I had done more work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done a helluva lot more than most people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale moves across the room to the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I chose freedom.  David was still in the thick of it, his life full of anxiety and studio intrigue.  I didn't fancy spending my golden years as merely "the friend."  The dirty little secret of a nervous producer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long were you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty years.  Too long.  We were like a play whose run outlasted the cast's ability to keep it fresh. So I finally decided to close down the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale places a pill on his tongue and swallows.  He fixes Clay with a pinched smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When all fetters are loosened, a certain hedonism creeps in, don't you think?  There was a period when this house was overrun with young men.  Some even posed for me. Right where you're sitting now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay sits uncomfortably in his chair.  His face flushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, they weren't nearly as bashful.  No, this room was once filled with bare buttocks.  And pricks.  Hard, arrogant pricks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay explodes out of his chair, knocking over a small sid table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it.  I can't do this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looms over Whale, whose breathing starts to quicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it enough you told me you're a fairy?  Do you have to rub my nose in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you, Mr. Boone, I meant no --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on, Mr. Whale, I cut your grass and that's it.  Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Whale can respond Clay storms out, nearly ripping screen door off its hinges.  Whale sits on the daybed, ta a few quick breaths.  Suddenly the air is filled with the sounds of people cavorting in the pool. Whale looks up, sees a young man standing outside the scr door.  It is now dark outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jimmy.  Watch me dive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale offers a melancholy smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll just rest for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man shrugs, disappears into the shadows.  We move across the room and through the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sits in a director's chair, a martini in one hand, cigar in the other, a harmless old uncle watching young m swagger and splash in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances over, sees Clay in plaid bathing trunks, sitti apart from the others.  He is puffing on a Camel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're up, Mr. Boone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay ignores him.  Whale puts down his martini and cigar, picks up a Polaroid camera.  He moves over to clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The extras are in their places. Now we need the star.  Wouldn't you like to get in the pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.  I never swim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale removes Clay's cigarette, crushes it with his shoe. Behind him, the pool is now a pit full of naked shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to remove that shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale touches Clay's bare chest.  Clay grabs hold of his wrist, causing the old man to yelp in pain.  In the pool, the extras shriek in alarm. Clay's hands close tightly around Whale's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's hands fly to his throat.  He opens his eyes and gasps greedily for air, the young men's screams lingering in the room.  There is a look of genuine terror on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun goes down.  Clay wearily pushes his lawnmower, struggling to concentrate on the darkened lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smug PROPERTY OWNER peers out at Clay from behind a screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind turning on a light? It's getting pretty soupy out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should have been here when you said you would.  You whack off a tow, don't think about taking me to court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lucky I even squeezed you in today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take that tone with me, bub. There's Japs in this town that work cheaper and do flowers too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay takes a deep breath.  He can't afford to get angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just turn on the porch light?  Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner flicks on the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay presses through the Saturday night crowd.  Clay cran his neck to scan the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Betty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took the night off.  Heavy date.  Some guy she's had her eye on for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry smiles pointedly at Clay, hands him the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns his back on the bar.  He sees Dwight moving through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight nods, a little coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Boone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dwight's WIFE, a pert, steely-eyed brunette, places a fir hand on his shoulder.  Dwight shrugs, heads toward the do Clay turns.  A pretty, too-tan BLONDE WOMAN in her early is standing at the end of the bar, eyeing Clay.  He lifts his glass and she responds with an open smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay and the woman go at it, their shadows visible throug the glass louvers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay tugs on a cord and the harsh overhead fluorescent buzzes to life.  He splashes his face with water, then catches his reflection in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay parks outside the local branch of the public library

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay leafs through an oversized folio, bound copies of Th New York Times.  He glances at an article from 1936.  "Interview With a Passing Whale."  There is a pict of Whale, captioned "Famous British Director."  A LIBRARI approaches with more leatherbound books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are the trade newspapers you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay takes the books, opens one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale eats lunch off a TV tray.  His attention remains focused on "Queen for a Day" as Hanna clomps into the roo behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that at the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale turns.  His face registers surprise when he sees Cl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Hanna.  That will be all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna retreats toward the kitchen.  Clay steps tentativel into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boone.  You're not due to cut the lawn until Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to sit for you again.  But only if you ease up on the locker room talk.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale holds up two fingers, affects an American accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scout's honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale and Boone are back in their familiar positions.  An empty glass of beer sits on the floor next to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm curious, Mr. Boone.  What convinced you to come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I guess I like your stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has stories to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your stint in Korea? I'm sure it was full of dramatic episodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.  I don't like to talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale nods, sensing that he's touched a sore spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the fear you showed at our last session?  How did you overcome that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not fear.  More like disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same difference, Mr. Boone. Disgust, fear of the unknown -- all part of the great gulf that stands between us.  Am I right in assuming that you've had little experience with men of my persuasion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no people like you in my crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No teammates in football?  No comrades in Korea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think the whole world is queer.  Well it's not.  War sure isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there may not be atheists in the foxholes, but there are occasionally lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking through your hat now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.  I was in the foxholes myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was an officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay breaks his pose to turn and look at Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was World War I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my dear.  The Crimean War. What do you think?  The Great War. You had a Good War, while we had --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale clears his throat, bored by his standard line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a war without end.  There were trenches when I arrived, and trenches when I left, two years later.  Just like in the movies. Only the movies never get the stench of them.  The world reduced to mud and sandbags and a narrow strip of rainy sky. (a dry snort) But we were discussing something else.  Oh yes.  Love in the trenches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's talking only to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnett.  Was that his name? Leonard Barnett.  He came to the front straight from Harrow.  And he looked up to me.  Unlike the others, he didn't care that I was a workingman impersonating his betters.  How strange, to be admired so blindly.  I suppose he loved me.  But chastely, like a schoolboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale looks up at Clay, stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember one morning in particular.  A morning when the sun came out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEONARD BARNETT, 19, boyish and handsome, peers into a periscope.  Whale stands beside him, pointing out landmar on the bleak landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Odd, how even there one could have days when the weather was enough to make one happy.  He and I were standing on the fire step and I showed him the sights of no-man's land, through the periscope.  It was beautiful.  The barbed wire was reddish gold, the water in the shell holes green with algae, the sky a clear quattrocento blue.  And I stood shoulder to shoulder with a tall apple-cheeked boy who loved and trusted me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale reaches over and lays his arm across Barnett's shoulder.  Barnett smiles timidly at him.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale leans forward, completely disoriented.  His eyes fi on Clay, the white eyebrows screwed down, until he is abl to recognize the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do this to me again, Mr. Boone.  I absolutely refuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stands, his legs shaky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not set me on another walk down memory lane.  Not this lane. Not today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I tell you this?  I never told David.  I never even remembered it until you got me going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one who started it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very clever, Mr. Boone.  You just sit there and let me talk. What a sorry old man, you're thinking.  What a crazy old poof. (comes closer) Why are you here?  What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked me to model.  Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I remember.  Do you think I'm so senile --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stands over Clay.  His pale face turns left, right, looking at Clay with one cold eye, then the other.  Clay returns the gaze, worried for Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?  Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale turns away.  He yanks out a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid.  Very stupid.  What have I been thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on the daybed and bends over, covering both eyes with the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go.  Please.  Why don't you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.  First you creep me out with homo shit.  Then you hit me with war stories.  And now you're upset because I listen? What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want -- I want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His pained eyes focus on Clay, and soften.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay gets up and goes to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A touch of headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay hands him the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sets the glass down and sits with his head lowered, his body folded like a bundle of sticks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My apologies.  I had no business snapping at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No harm done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was foolishness to attempt this portrait.  You cannot force what will not flow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want me to sit for you anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale shakes his head sadly.  He gazes up at Clay, sees t disappointment on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to come to a party with me?  A reception for Princess Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you weren't going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind driving, I'd like to take you as my guest.  There should be lots of pretty starlets to keep you amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm game.  Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Clayton.  May I call you Clayton?  Or do you prefer Boone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clayton is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale smiles gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting over the Pacific.  Clay stands in a ph booth on the strand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay smiles anxiously as the call connects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom?  Yeah, it's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay pauses as his mother shoots questions at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not in jail...I don't want any money, no... (louder, to be heard) Look, is Sis there?  I want to tell her about this movie person I met out here.  She'll get a kick out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the phrase: "She's out, Clay."  Clay closes his e as his mother rambles on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I still...I'd give you my phone number if I had a phone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay tries to stay calm as his mother berates him for not staying in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Clay can protest we hear: "Hold on."  Clay glances out at couples strolling up the promenade.  An operator interrupts, says: "One dollar for the next three minutes. Clay deposits two quarters before his mother returns. "He's busy, Clay."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The operator comes on again, asking for fifty more cents. Clay stares at the quarters in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time's up.  I better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay listens as his mother prattles on, until the connect is broken and the phone goes dead.  Clay steps out of the booth, takes a deep breath of ocean air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale and Hanna go through the closet together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boone.  He is an interesting friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd hardly call our yardman a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But someone you can talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stops, turns to Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you miss having someone to talk to, Hanna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my family.  Also our Lord Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.  How is the old boy these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The naughty remark is met with a solemn stare.  Whale reaches up, chooses a lightweight blue suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It needs a hat.  There was a wide-brimmed cream fedora...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be up in your old room.  I will look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings.  Hanna hurries to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna speaks softly in Hungarian.  Whale points upstairs let her know he will look for the hat himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale opens the closet door and takes down a stack of hatboxes from the overhead shelf.  He opens the first box takes out a rubbery wad of heavy fabric with two round windows like eyes.  It's a gas mask.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night sky explodes with light and smoke.  Whale moves calmly through the chaos, trying to maintain a modicum of order among the troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas masks on.  Gas masks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the line, young Barnett is struggling with straps.  Mustard gas is starting to stream into the trenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind me, Lieutenant.  Save yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale slips the mask over Barnett's face, fastens it.  He slides his own mask into position moments before the tren is obliterated by the yellowish smoke.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna stands in the door with a forlorn frown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Jimmy.  You make a mess of it.  Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna lifts the lid of an unopened box to show him the missing fedora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stacking boxes) That is my daughter.  She say she and her husband are coming to town this afternoon.  I am sorry, Mr. Jimmy.  I will make it short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be out this afternoon, remember?  Your family can visit as long as they like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I do not cook for them.  My daughter's no-good husband will not take one bite of our food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna holds out the box for the gas mask.  Whale gives it long, final look, then drops it in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can toss this one in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna clamps the lid on the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna has opened the door.  At the end of the hall, silhouetted against the bright afternoon sky, is Clay.  H shoulders fill the doorway.  The top of his head is perfectly flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay steps into the light.  His khaki pants are clean and pressed.  A blue knit shirt fits his muscles snugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look splendid, my boy.  Quite splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale crosses to the passenger side of the Chrysler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you'd like the top down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing would please me more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay squeezes behind the wheel, shifts the seat back, explores switches.  The vinyl top pops up and folds backward. Whale gets in.  Clay starts the engine and backs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna stands at the front door, hands tangled in her apro Whale tugs his hat brim at her as the car swings around t driveway. Whale smiles at the wide open sky overhead.  Clay steps o the gas and the Chrysler takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is clearly audible from the road, where Clay ha squeezed the Chrysler into a long row of shiny cars nuzzl the high brick wall.  Whale puts his dark glasses on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stars, you know.  The suns of other galaxies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk up the steep road to the gatehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old George.  He loves to put on the dog.  Only his dogs tend to have a bit of mutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN at the gate inspects the invitation, waves them through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sunny patio with hedges and statues.  Wickets and stake have been set up for a game of croquet, but only a handfu of very tanned children strut around with mallets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you?  Listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  Cukor was too cheap to hire music.  There's nothing but chin-wag.  The cold dreary custard of English chin-wag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale scans the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slim pickings.  Well, it's early yet.  Perhaps this is a good time to pay our respects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay follows Whale toward a trellis alcove covered in ivy A handful of people grin at the mismatched couple who sta in the shade: a homely older man in glasses and a pretty woman in a white dress with polka dots.  GEORGE CUKOR and PRINCESS MARGARET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get this over with quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale forgets to remove his hat when he comes forward. Before he can give Cukor their names Princess Margaret's polite smile bursts open in a joyful display of teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea you'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seizes Whale's hand in her little white gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Fine.  Quite fine.  And Your Royal Highness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid.  Now that I know you're around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing beside him, Clay is clearly impressed that Whale knows a princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get together while I'm in town?  I so badly want to sit for you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've changed my hair, you see. Since our last session.  Those old snaps look rather dowdy now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale realizes she's mistaken him for someone else.  He t his sunglasses down his nose so she can see his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.  Have I made a blunder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, the pleasure is all mine.  James Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) I am such a goose.  I mistook you for Cecil Beaton.  It's the hat. You're wearing one of Cecil's hats, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale attempts to chuckle while he fights a feeling of humiliation.  He turns to Cukor for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, George.  James Whale.  David Lewis's friend.  I once made pictures myself, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Of course.  One can't throw a rock in this town without hitting one of us old movie directors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale feels the sting.  He turns to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, may I present Mr. Clayton Boone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay steps forward to shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My gardener, who insisted I bring him today.  He so wanted to meet royalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cukor's face goes blank with indignation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite.  I adore gardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale narrows his eyes at Cukor and sharpens his smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's never met a princess.  Only queens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cukor puffs out his chest, quivers a bulbous lower lip at Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, Ma'am, this has been an honor.  An occasion to remember for the rest of my days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads Clay away and an American couple promptly crowd to take their place.  Striding through the garden, Whale obviously pleased with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing of importance.  Just two old men slapping each other with lilies.  Shall we have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale leads Clay to a tented bar.  Across the way, David Lewis has come through the gate with a WOMAN on his arm. People look discreetly, not at David but at the woman, lightly veiled in a scarf and sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David.  The friend I thought was in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  The girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl?  Oh.  Elizabeth Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay watches in amazement as ELIZABETH TAYLOR waves to someone and pipes out a happy hello.  She hurriedly untie her scarf, thrusts it at David and runs off on tiptoes to embrace a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that really her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David produced her last picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David glances around while he slips the scarf into a coat pocket.  He sees Whale looking at him.  He puts on a tigh smile and strolls across the patio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what I was about to ask you. I thought you were in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was, until last night.  Publicity asked me to fly Miss Taylor in for today's reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter arrives with their drinks.  Only when Clay tak his glass of beer does David see that Whale is not alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay Boone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our yardman.  Who was kind enough to serve as my escort to George's little do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David freezes.  Whale lifts his martini glass at Clay and takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should you be drinking in your condition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, David, stop being a nanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay clears his throat, eager to escape this domestic squabble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll go look at Elizabeth Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have seen Georgie's face when he met Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.  But Princess Margaret was a doll.  We're all equals in her eyes.  As commoners, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only embarrass yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.  I'll never work in this town again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.  Your reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have no reputation.  I'm as free as the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the rest of us aren't.  Can't you remember that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I never could.  You must regret having had the invitation sent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is looking over Whale's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask George to invite you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy, there are people here I need to speak to.  You'll be fine on your own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then.  I'll come by tomorrow for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale nods, watches David stroll over to the pool and gre a gaggle of executives.  Whale drifts toward some deck chairs at the far end of the croquet lawn.  He sits, take sip of his drink.  Suddenly a high-pitched giggle pierces the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale looks out to see Edmund Kay, his interviewer from several weeks ago, marching across the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr....Kay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you thought you'd never see me again.  I didn't know if you'd be well enough to come to this party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one who got you on Mr. Cukor's guest list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Mr. Kay?  How do you know George Cukor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I interviewed him after I met you. I'm his social secretary now. Well, assistant to his secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I commend you.  If you're going to pursue poofs, go after those who can do favors for you.  You waste everybody's time when you court dinosaurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think that, Mr. Whale.  I love your movies.  That's why I wanted you to come to this.  So I could see you with your monsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My monsters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale tries to do just that, but finds himself caught in chair.  He is stumbling to his feet when Kay returns with Elsa Lanchester, 55, at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy.  How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes Whale's hand, with a look of deep concern and sympathy.  Kay races off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw Una O'Conner a few weeks ago. She said you'd been under the weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing out of the ordinary. Growing old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all getting a bit long in the tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you appear quite fresh, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She swats aside the compliment and gestures at the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  You shouldn't stand on my account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly all right.  But if you'd like to sit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Jimmy.  I can only stay a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's our pesky friend up to now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay returns, accompanied by a stopped, gray-haired man wi a long rectangular face and wary, heavy-lidded eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Boris?  Our little chum appears to be arranging a reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karloff, age 70, comes reluctantly, followed by his niece ALICE, a bashful young woman who carried a blanket-wrappe bundle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris, darling.  I didn't know you were here.  These public revels are hardly up your alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came for the sake of my visiting niece.  Alice.  And Miranda, my great-niece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His huge hand lifts the blanket in Alice's arms, revealin bald infant with enormous blue eyes.  Karloff gurgles and coos at the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you make of our royal visitant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly charming.  A real lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she's a lady.  What did you expect?  A hussy in tennis shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale looks up and discovers Clay standing a few feet beh Karloff.  He is ogling two bosomy actresses who are listening intently to the monocled British consul. Whale's eyes try to focus Karloff and Clay together, his once and future monsters.  Kay shouts to a passing photographer carrying a bulky Speed Graphic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you!  With the camera!  We got a historical moment here.  Come get a picture of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man scans the scene for a famous face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. James Whale, who made "Frankenstein" and "Bride of Frankenstein."  and this is the Monster and his Bride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay looks up when he hears Kay identify Karloff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Karloff.  Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karloff and Elsa drift into position next to Whale.  The flash goes off, a snap and a crunch of light.  Whale crin in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through clenched teeth) Don't you just love being famous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another flash.  From Whale's perspective, the bulb resemb nothing so much as the translucent tube of electrical current from Dr. Frankenstein's laboratory.  Whale concentrates on his smile as another snap of light stabs brain.  He clutches Elsa Lanchester's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sharp nod from Whale.  The photographer motions to Karloff's niece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get one with Frankenstein holding the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice hands over the baby.  Karloff gently cradles the child.  Whale stands on his left, Elsa on his right.  The all smile at the baby, who gurgles and points up.  Whale follows the baby's gaze to the sky, where a large kite ro and strains in a furious electrical storm. The camera flashes once, then again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale glances up -- the kite is gone.  Thunder rumbles as the group starts to disperse.  Whale nods to the faces exchanging good-byes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So good to see you again, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strolls off, clucking and cooing at his baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch you before you go, Mr. Whale. I'll make sure everybody gets sent a print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes off with the photographer.  Elsa kisses Whale on cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be in touch, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good-bye.  So nice to see you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Whale is alone.  He staggers to the deck chair an lowers himself sideways into the lawn chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale gazes up at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired.  A bit tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay nods.  Whale smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you enjoying yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, no.  I feel a little out of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither of us really belongs here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must have been funny for you. Seeing your monsters again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsters?  The only monsters... (closes his eyes) ...are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the lawn, conversation has stopped.  Birdlike shri come from all directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fuck.  And we left the top down. You want to run for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you see?  It's raining!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain is only a flickering of air, but people are jump and shrieking, throwing coats over their heads as they da toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Whale under the arm, helps him up and escorts hi to a small tent.  On the patio, everyone shoves and squee to get through the one open door. Whale stares out, hypnotized by the deluge.  From his POV we see a young man step into the rain.  Whale squints, is finally able to identify the man as Leonard Barnett. Whale's eyes follow Barnett as he emerges onto a new landscape, a scarred and barren battlefield.  As the stor continues to rage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale shifts his gaze to Clay.  He takes a moment to orie himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of this funk hole

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to wait it out? Rain should let up soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sugar.  We won't melt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale adjusts the brim of his hat and steps into the downpour.  Clay has no choice except to follow.  They wal briskly, the minute splashes on Whale's hat forming a ghostly aura of spray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale opens the door and climbs in next to Clay.  The roo slowly closes over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get you home before you catch your death from pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch my death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay glances over, sees Whale sitting very wet and rigid, staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale blinks, slowly turns.  There is a cracked look in h eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy.  Please.  Call me Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay smiles, starts to back the car out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hallway is pitch-dark as Whale and Clay enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna!  Bring us some towels. We're drenched to the bone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blast her.  If we soil her holy floor, it's her own damn fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale goes squashing down the hall.  Clay remains just inside the open door, prying off his shoes and peeling of his socks.  He follows Whale into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stands over the table with his jaw open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides a note to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Just a night out.  Sounds like she can't say no to her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly you have better things to do than babysit an old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Let's get dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stands just inside the closet, buttoning a crisp wh shirt.  He reaches for a red bow tie, closes the closet door.  In the mirror, Leonard Barnett stands behind him, uniform.  Whale's eyes twinkle in surprise.  He drapes th tie around his collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnett smiles his approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay opens the bathroom door, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  He goes to the top of the stairs and calls ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's those clothes you promised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, nothing.  Rain ticks against the windows.  Clay go down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale fiddles with the knot of his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trusts me, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnett sits on the edge of the bed now.  He smiles, a bi sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's glow coming from the bedroom, and the sound of Whale's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?  Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay steps slowly toward the door, pushes it open.  He pe in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale pulls on a blazer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whale?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale jumps.  He slaps a hand over his chest, twists arou sees Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of course.  Clayton.  You finished your shower already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes ago.  Didn't you hear me calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not.  Terribly sorry. (stands) I believe I promised you some clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale crosses to the closet.  Barnett is nowhere to be se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're much wider than I am.  You won't want to attempt to get into my pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Definitely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay chuckles.  Whale smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a robe from a hook on the closet door.  Clay tri it on but it won't close over the towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale opens a drawer, takes out a crewneck sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely swims on me, but should take care of your upper half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay pulls the sweater over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That only leaves the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have any baggy shorts? Pajama bottoms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  My pajamas are tailored. Would it be too distressing to continue with the towel?  No more immodest than a kilt, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have any other choice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very sporting of you, Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay notices a framed drawing on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) The only memento I ever kept.  My original sketch for the Monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the sketch to Clay, who stares down at the famou flat head, hooded eyes, bolted neck of the Monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay puts down the sketch, starts into the hall.  Whale turns back, sees Barnett standing by the window.  Whale flips off the light and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay sits at the kitchen table.  Whale opens the refrigerator and brings out two plates wrapped in wax pap and a bottle of beer for Clay.  He pours himself a shot o Scotch from a decanter and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner, if Hanna isn't back? Can we try a few more sketches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd given up on my picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to try again.  If you're game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  Give us something to do while we wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay munches on his sandwich.  Whale pours himself anothe Scotch, takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Clayton.  Do you believe in mercy killing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never gave it much thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now.  I'm sure you came across such situations in Korea.  A wounded comrade, or perhaps one of the enemy?  Someone for whom death would be a blessing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay stops chewing.  He stares down at his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a deep breath, looks up at Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never made it to Korea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that I was a Marine.  Which is true.  You filled in the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay downs his beer, refills the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My old man was a Marine.  He enlisted the day he turned seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Great War?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) By the time he was ready to ship out, the fighting was over.  He missed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very lucky thing indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the way he saw it.  To him, it was like his life never got started.  Nothing else really mattered.  Definitely not his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale gazes sympathetically at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning after Pearl Harbor, he drove down to St. Louis to reenlist.  He was so damn excited. World War II was going to be his second chance. (sighs) They told him he was too old...fat ...nearsighted.  Said he'd be more use to his country if he stayed home and looked after his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you joined the Marines? For your father's sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured he'd think, you know -- it was the next best thing.  Hey, I loved it too.  A chance to be a part of something important. Something bigger than yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have the guts for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of surprise crosses Whale's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, literally.  My body screwed me up.  Burst appendix. They gave me a medical discharge. All I thought about was, how am I going to tell the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks into a crooked smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what he did when I called him?  He laughed.  He laughed so hard he practically burst a blood vessel.  Said it was a good lesson for me.  Not to try to fill his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them's the breaks, right?  No war stories for this pup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where you're wrong, Clayton. You've just told one.  A very good story indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale lifts his glass in a toast.  Clay empties his glass beer.  He motions toward the decanter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the decanter to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay sits in a straight-backed chair, smoking a cigarette and sipping his Scotch.  Whale sketches from a wing chair across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storm's getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A perfect night for mystery and horror.  The air itself is filled with monsters."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's from your movie, right? "The only monsters are here."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Whale.  This afternoon at the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it must be weird seeing your monsters again, and you said, "The only monsters are here."  I was wondering which here you meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't recall.  Memories of the war, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that was so long ago.  It can't still bother you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but it does.  Especially in light of the journey I'm about to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're planning a trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's gaze remains dreamy and preoccupied as SOUNDS of battle fill the room.  A relentless rat-a-tat of gunfire. The whistling of bombs.  The tortured wailing of dying me Whale stands, moves over to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnett.  Barnett on the wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale gazes out at the storm.  From his POV, we see a scarred and barren landscape, illuminated by occasional flashes of lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He caught his one night coming back from the reconnoiter.  I wouldn't take him out, but McGill did.  Just to give the lad a taste.  They were nearly home when a Maxim gun opened fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We race along the open trench with Whale, the darkened sk intermittently punctured by bursts of gunfire.  He reache the periscope, pulls an enlisted man off it.  From his PO we see Barnett and McGill dodging bullets as they attempt make their way back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through clenched teeth) Come on.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McGill leaps over the barbed wire of a forward trench. Barnett follows.  Just as his feet leave the ground his chest is riddled by a fresh round of gunfire.  Whale's ey snap closed, trying to obliterate what they've just seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnett's body fell in wire as thick as briers.  It was hanging there the next morning, a hundred yards from the line, too far out for anyone to fetch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale stares out impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw him at morning stand-to and evening stand-to.  "Good morning, Barnett," we'd say each day. "How's ole Barnett looking this morning?"  "Seems a little peaky. Looks a little plumper."  His wounds faced the other way and his hat shielded his eyes, so one could imagine he was napping on bedsprings.  He hung there until we were relieved.  We introduced him to the new unit before we marched out, speaking highly of his companionship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's eyes are filled with pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but we were a witty lot. Laughing at our dead.  Telling ourselves it was our death too. But with each man who died, I thought, "Better you than me, poor sod." (bitterly) A whole generation was wiped out by that war.  Millions and millions of young men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale begins to hum, a tune we have heard before:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh death where is thy sting-a-ling? Grave where thy victory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You survived it.  It can't hurt you now.  It's no good to dig it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, my friend.  It's digging itself up.  There is nothing in the here and now to take my mind off it.  All my diversions have abandoned me.  Parties.  Reading. Painting.  Work.  Love.  All gone to me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale remains perfectly still, staring out the window.  C deliberates a moment, then puts down his drink next to th decanter of Scotch.  He stands and yanks the neck of the  sweater over his face, then tosses it on the sofa.  Whale blinks at the reflection in the glass, not yet  understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to draw me like a Greek statue.  All right, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay pulls at the knot, lets go of the towel.  He defiant parks his hands on his hips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.  Not so bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale continues to stare at the reflection, his back to Clay, his eyes wide and expressionless.  He turns slowly, fully expecting the vision to evaporate.  When he sees th Clay is truly naked he mutters softly under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is going to happen after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale doesn't respond.  Finally he opens his mouth to tak breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It won't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What won't do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are much too human.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you expect?  Bronze?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale moves abruptly across the room.  He walks past Clay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale passes quickly through the dining room and out to t kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale reaches for the hatbox, which sits on top of a garb can.  Suddenly a large hand appears on the box.  Whale ga when a flash of lightning reveals the face of the Monster The Monster growls out an inarticulate greeting.  He pick up the box and hands it to Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale removes the lid, sets the hatbox on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like you to wear this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale steps back.  Clay takes the box and covers his lap with it.  He lifts out the gas mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the artistic effect.  The combination of your human body and that inhuman mask.  It's quite striking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Clayton.  Just for a minute.  Long enough for me to see the effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from the first World War, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) There are straps in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay fits the mask on the top of his head and draws it do The living room turns brownish yellow in the thick glass goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale is suddenly behind him.  Clay's vision is enclosed two round windows, so he can't see Whale buckling the sec strap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
