dialogues.text: Mouth muffled by the inhalator, Clay hears his voice from inside his head.  Whale comes around to stand in front of him.  He grins as he steps back to examine Clay.  Clay nervously taps his knees with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Let's take it off now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay raises his voice to make himself heard.  He reaches back to undo the buckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale steps in past the goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want to tear the straps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay drops his hands so Whale can undo the buckles.  But nothing happens.  Clay turns left and right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  I am still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hands grip Clay's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What steely muscles, Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's hands squeeze.  Clay grabs the frame of his seat, stop his arms from automatically swinging a fist.  Whale' hand slides over Clay's shoulder to his arm, caressing th tattoo.  Clay jerks his shoulder to shake Whale off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take off the fucking mask!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Clayton.  I can't hear you. I can't hear a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale presses his lips to Clay's tattoo.  Clay's muscles tense from head to toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a solid brute you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's tongue moves down Clay's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?  Maybe this, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand slides over Clay's stomach toward his lap.  The tattooed arm swings backward, slamming an elbow against Whale's skull.  Clay jumps from the chair, knocking into end table.  The glass and crystal decanter fall to the floor.  The lamp spills over and the room goes dark. Clay's ankle is caught by the sofa leg and he hits the floor, jamming the inhalator against his mouth.  He quick gets up, on his knees and elbows, pulling at the mask. Flashes of lightning strobe the room as Whale collapses o Clay's back and holds on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  I have you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strap breaks.  Clay rips the mask off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's hand squeezes between Clay's legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will you do to get yourself back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay jabs with his elbow, flipping Whale on his back.  Hi body straddles Whale's and pins him, face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not that way.  Get it through your fucking head.  I don't want to mess with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but you feel good, Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hands clasp Clay's hips.  Clay's fist opens as it com down; he slaps Whale across the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That didn't even sting.  You're not such a real man after all.  Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay whacks Whale's face again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait until I tell my friends I had you naked in my arms.  Won't they be surprised?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't done a damn thing with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but you have.  You undressed for me.  I kissed you.  I even touched your prick.  How will you be able to live with yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay snatches Whale's wrist before it can touch his crotc With his other hand he picks up the heavy crystal decante

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you want from me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale tilts his face up for another blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay freezes.  He stares down at the old man with white h and wild eyes lying beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break my neck.  Or strangle me.  It would be oh so easy to wrap your hands around my neck and choke the life out of me.  Please, Clayton. We've come this far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale's eyes glimmer in the sporadic bursts of lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly, I'm losing my mind. Every day, another piece goes. Soon there will be nothing left. Look at the sketch I made of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay turns to the sketch pad, which lies on the floor nex to Whale.  The page is filled with nothing but doodles an scrawls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you want to die do it yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want to die alone.  But to be killed by you -- that would make death bearable.  They say you never see the one with your name on it.  But I want to see death coming at me.  I want it to be sharp and hard, with a human face.  Your face.  Think, Clayton.  You'd be my second Monster.  Almost as famous as the first.  It would be the great adventure you've yearned for. A war story for both of us to share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's breathing comes in quick, panicked bursts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be fully exonerated, I've taken care of that.  I wrote a note, I'll even leave you the house, the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay's body starts to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it now, Clayton.  Make me invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay lets out a howl -- his shoulders heave and shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not your monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs off Whale, crawls away, his body collapsing in wracking, anguished sobs.  Whale opens his eyes, gazes at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I done? (sits up) Oh, selfish, selfish fool.  I have lost my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He forces himself to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale picks up the towel and moves over to Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a softhearted bloke.  A bloody pussycat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale places the towel around Clay's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My deepest apologies.  Can you ever forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose not. (a bone-crushing sigh) Good God, I am tired.  I really must go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale starts slowly down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale sits on the edge of the bed, tugs the bowtie from h collar.  Clay taps on the door, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing I didn't deserve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need some help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray you, undo this button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts his chin and points to his collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can never manage it when I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay leans in to open the button.  His face is only six inches from Whale's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe people come into our lives for a reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay doesn't answer.  Whale turns, breaking their shared gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can undress myself, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (steps back) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale hauls his legs up and stretches out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you die...be sure your brain is the last organ to fizzle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll feel better tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale smiles fondly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Clayton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay pulls the door shut and it clicks.  He stands there moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay shakes open a bedsheet and wraps himself in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay finds a pack of cigarettes on the floor and lights o then sets the furniture back up.  He picks up the gas mas from beside the sofa, shoves it into its box. Clay sits in the wing-back chair, props his feet on the hassock, adjusting the sheet around his shoulders.  We CU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whale bolts up in bed.  An electrical storm flashes and cracks in the window. Whale gets out of bed, stares outside.  From his POV, the lawn is a barren slope covered with stumps. Whale turns on the desk lamp, sits.  He pulls out a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're back to the scene that opened the movie, a flat-top creature stumbling through the mud.  A flash of lightning reveals Clay's face.  He turns, signals for Whale to foll him.  Whale joins Clay on a slight rise of ground, the ri of a crater.  Clay points down into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crater is full of bodies gathered around a pool of water.  Whale stumbles down, reaches the bottom and bends over the nearest corpse in khaki.  It is Leonard Barnett. There are no wounds on his body, no rips or gaping holes. His eyes are closed in dreamless sleep. Whale looks up and sees that Clay is gone.  The only othe living creature is an owl, which blinks wearily at him. Whale lies down, finding a spot next to Barnett.  He take last breath and closes his eyes.  We CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roar of bells blasts Clay awake.  The telephone is ringing.  A hard pair of shoes thunder out to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Oh, Mr. David!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay blinks at the sight of Hanna in black dress and whit apron, chattering on the phone by the far wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, he did not tell me.  But no problem.  I will make breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scoldingly cuts her eyes at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten?  Very good, then.  Good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and faces Clay with a stern frown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have brought you your clothes. All I ask is that you get dressed and go.  We are having a guest for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you about Mr. Whale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing you can say that will surprise me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  But I still need to talk. Do I have time for a cup of coffee before I go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I blame my daughter for keeping me out so late.  I only hope you did not get him excited.  It could give him a new stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stomps into the kitchen.  Clay gets up, slips on his undershorts.  He's zipping up his chinos when she comes o again with a breakfast tray.  She hands him a cup of coff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (quickly) Why do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of Mr. Whale like he was your flesh and blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my job.  I did it when he was happy and it was easy.  It is only fair I do it now when he is ill. (picks up the tray) Enough talk.  I must wake up the master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She marches around the corner towards Whale's bedroom.  C hears her knocking on a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jimmy?  Morning, Mr. Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay pulls on his shirt.  Hanna comes back around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put him to bed.  He's not there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the foot of the stairs and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jimmy!  Mr. Jimmy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay reaches for his socks when he notices an envelope on the floor next to the chair.  He picks it up.  On the fro is scrawled the word 'CLAYTON'.  Clay opens the envelope. Inside is Whale's original sketch of the Monster's head. turns it over.  There is a message written on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay drops the sketch, looks out.  He sees something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay crosses the patio, hurtles down the slope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay leaps headfirst into the water.  Whale rests lightly his back, with an upward sway of straight white hair.  Cl hauls the body toward the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost there.  Almost there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets an arm around Whale's chest and heaves the body o the curb.  he climbs out, drags the body forward to rest the grass.  He grabs the wrist.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch.  You crazy son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay straddles Whale's thighs and applies pressure on his rib cage.  But it's no use.  Clay sits up and takes a dee breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna comes down the path, her run slowing to a walk.  Sh stares at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do it.  This wasn't me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted me to kill him, but I didn't.  He did it himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says here good-bye.  I find it in his room.  He is sorry, he says. He has had a wonderful life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves a folded piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You poor, foolish man.  You couldn't wait for God to take you in his time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay slowly stands up.  Hanna looks around in panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must leave.  You were not here this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police will not know that. They will want to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have his note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to be questioned about you and Mr. Jimmy?  Please, Clayton.  It will be better if I find the body alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how're you going to explain this? (points at the body) How did you get him out of the pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are right.  Yes.  We must put him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both hesitate, looking down at Whale.  Then Clay dra the body parallel with the pool.  Hanna stoops over to adjust the collar of Whale's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Mr. Jimmy.  We do not mean disrespect.  You will keep better in water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods to Clay.  He rolls the body over and it splashes its belly.  It bounces a moment in the waves of the splas then begins to sink.  As it drops, the air in the chest slowly flips the body around. Looking up at them with open eyes, Whale sinks backward i the thickening light.  His arms trail upward and the hand lightly flutter as if waving good-bye.  The melancholy so of a solo violin pierces the silence as we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black-and-white scene from "Bride of Frankenstein."  Th old BLIND MAN plays a mournful lullaby on his violin whil the MONSTER listens outside, moved by the music.  He smas open the door of the hut in an effort to get closer to th soul-soothing sound.  The blind man stops playing, looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?  You're welcome, my friend, whoever you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monster attempts to communicate, manages only a plaintive moan.  The blind man stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot see you.  I cannot see anything.  You must please excuse me.  But I am blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Monster holds out his burned hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, my poor friend.  No one will hurt you here.  If you're in trouble, perhaps I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man touches the Monster, who recoils with a defensive growl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you not speak?  It's strange. Perhaps you're afflicted too.  I cannot see and you cannot speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL BOONE, 10, lies on the living room carpet, starin raptly at the movie playing on the large Zenith console. The house is small but tidy and comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long time since any human being came into this hut.  I shall look after you.  And you will comfort me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the tv screen, the old man starts to cry, then collaps onto the Monster's chest.  A thick tear rolls down the Monster's cheek. Clay Boone sits on the sofa, a baby on his lap.  He's 40 now, his hair starting to thin but still closely cropped the top and sides. On the tv, daylight fills the hut.  The blind man and the Monster share a meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are friends, you and I. Friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you came, I was all alone. It is bad to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, bad.  Friend, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the old man's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blind man nods.  On the sofa, Clay watches his son wa the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A color promo for "Chiller Theater" fills the screen.  Cl turns off the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for bed, sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael groans, slowly stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you think of the movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty cool.  Better than most monster movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew the guy who made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael glances skeptically at his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Dad.  Is this another one of your stories?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay unfolds Whale's sketch of the Monster, hands it to h son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his original sketch of the Monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael turns over the sketch.  On the back, scrawled in block letters: "TO CLAYTON BOONE -- FRIEND?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay nods.  At the same time, his wife DANA appears in th doorway.  A pretty, cheerful woman in her mid-30s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trash, Clay.  Before it rains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay kisses the top of his son's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay carries a large metal bin down the tidy lawn.  The s momentarily brightens with a silent flash of lightning. Clay gazes up at the electrical storm.  He glances back a his house, sees Dana cradling the baby in an upstairs window. The skies open with a shattering crash of thunder.  Clay tilts up his face, drinks in the cool rain.  Then he exte his arms and staggers along the sidewalk, imitating the Monster's famous lurch. We PULL BACK, revealing a sleepy neighborhood of small houses and neat lawns, until Clay is only a small dot in landscape. FADE OUT.
